event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item: Schedule an urgent repair action to replace the memory module indicated by 'fmadm faulty'.
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: A memory module has suffered an uncorrectable error.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
This message ID: GMCA-8001-09 indicates that the Solaris Fault Manager has received reports of Uncorrectable Multiple-Bit memory errors associated with a Memory Module have been detected, and a Memory Module fault has been diagnosed. No data has been lost, and pages of the affected Memory Module are being retired as errors are encountered.

The recommended service action for this event is to schedule replacement of the affected Memory Module(s) at the earliest possible convenience.

Follow the steps below to complete the recommended repair action.

Step 1: Find the 36 character EVENT_ID string associated with the fault.

Use fmdump (1M) shown in Example 1.1 below, or extract it from the fault message displayed in the console output at the time of the fault.

Note: Be sure to get the correct 36 character EVENT_ID string if more than one is listed. You can identify the correct string by associating the fault with the date and time stamp in Example 1.1

    Example 1.1 - finding the EVENT_ID (36 character string):

LEGEND:
BLUE = EVENT_ID
RED = SUNW-MSG-ID

    
# fmdump
TIME                 UUID                                 SUNW-MSG-ID
Nov 24 08:52:11.8258 813c6dfd-fbbd-ed99-f70d-e9ebded96133 GMCA-8001-09
Dec 05 12:39:50.7994 3721bbfb-0a15-cec6-c925-dea615446c11 GMCA-8000-T0
Step 2: Use the command; fmdump -v -u EVENT_ID, to locate the faulty memory module, where EVENT_ID consists of the 36 character string obtained in Step 1 above. See Example 2.1 below.

    Example 2.1 - determining which FRU needs to be replaced:

LEGEND:
GREEN = FRU
BLUE = EVENT_ID
RED = SUNW-MSG-ID

    
# fmdump -v -u  813c6dfd-fbbd-ed99-f70d-e9ebded96133 
TIME                 UUID                                 SUNW-MSG-ID
Nov 24 08:52:11.8258 813c6dfd-fbbd-ed99-f70d-e9ebded96133 GMCA-8001-09
  100%  fault.memory.generic-x86.dimm_ue

        Problem in: hc://:product-id=Sun-Fire-X4600-M2:chassis-id=0806AM0254:server-id=sx64-x4600m2a-bur02/
          motherboard=0/chip=0/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/chip-select=0
           Affects: mem:///motherboard=0/chip=0/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/chip-select=0
               FRU: -
          Location: CPU 0 DIMM 0

Step 3: Replace the faulty FRU in our case Dimm 0 associated with CPU 0 (and reboot the system)

Refer to the service label or hardware maintenance manual for correct replacement procedures.

Step 4: Update the Fault Manager's resource cache to indicate that no problems are present in the resources that had been diagnosed faulty and subsequently replaced in Step 3. Shown in Example 4.1

Once the Memory Modules have been physically replaced and the system rebooted, you must invoke the 'fmadm repair' command using the UUID (Universally Unique IDentifier) to identify the repaired FRU. The UUID is synonymous with the EVENT_ID (highlighted in blue) in Example 1.1 above.

    Example 4.1 - Updating the Fault Manager's resource cache: 
    # fmadm repair  813c6dfd-fbbd-ed99-f70d-e9ebded96133 
# fmadm: recorded repair to  813c6dfd-fbbd-ed99-f70d-e9ebded96133

Step 5: Reset the Faulted Page Counters.

Once the fmadm repair <UUID> has completed reset the Faulted Page counter, you must invoke the 'fmadm reset' command shown in Example 5.1 below. The required action in this step is temporary. When this becomes automated this article will be updated to reflect these changes.

    Example 5.1 - Reset Faulted Page Counters 
    # fmadm reset eft

Note: By resetting the Faulted Page Counters, this will reset ALL diagnosis state for the diagnosis engine. All event history will be lost. All Already diagnosed faults will continue to appear in fmadm faulty. Before resetting capture the outputs from fmstat -m eft, fmstat -s -m eft.

Step 6: Verify the repaired resource is no longer faulty

Use the Solaris command 'fmadm faulty' to display all faulted resources in the system. Confirm that the repaired resource is no longer listed as faulted shown in Example 6.1.

    Example 6.1 - verifying the repaired resource is no longer faulty: 
    # fmadm faulty
   STATE RESOURCE / UUID
-------- ----------------------------------------------------------------------

event_registry_properties.item: Page retirement (where supported) is capped at a small fraction of memory to avoid performance impact.
event_registry_properties.name: response
event_registry_properties.item: If Solaris is running on bare-metal (native) then affected memory pages associated with this memory module will be removed from service.
